name: Leopard Prawn
textHtml: Cousins to the Yanxian tiger prawn, these crustaceans are scrutinized at market like a cut of expensive beef─per the gastronomically astute, the more vivid and varied the pattern of the carapace, the richer the flesh will be.
textClean: Cousins to the Yanxian tiger prawn, these crustaceans are scrutinized at market like a cut of expensive beef─per the gastronomically astute, the more vivid and varied the pattern of the carapace, the richer the flesh will be.

name: Crimson Kelp
textHtml: A number of Far Eastern gastronomical experts rate crimson kelp among the most indispensable ingredients in Far Eastern cuisine. Prepared in a multitude of mouthwatering ways, it sees use in stock, seasoning, and as a dish unto itself.
textClean: A number of Far Eastern gastronomical experts rate crimson kelp among the most indispensable ingredients in Far Eastern cuisine. Prepared in a multitude of mouthwatering ways, it sees use in stock, seasoning, and as a dish unto itself.

name: Reef Squid
textHtml: Though these wavekin's migration pattern covers most Far Eastern waters, it is to the Ruby Sea's rocky reefs that they return to deposit their eggs. Relatively average as far as stature is concerned, reef squid typically grow to two fulms at the longest.
textClean: Though these wavekin's migration pattern covers most Far Eastern waters, it is to the Ruby Sea's rocky reefs that they return to deposit their eggs. Relatively average as far as stature is concerned, reef squid typically grow to two fulms at the longest.

name: Pinebark Flounder
textHtml: These flounder were given their arboreal appellation for the bark-like patterns that mark their scales. Prized as delicacies by the upper echelons of Kugane, the wavekin are sold directly to the finest eateries in the city, and thus are rarely ever seen at market.
textClean: These flounder were given their arboreal appellation for the bark-like patterns that mark their scales. Prized as delicacies by the upper echelons of Kugane, the wavekin are sold directly to the finest eateries in the city, and thus are rarely ever seen at market.

name: Catching Carp
textHtml: Found in freshwater sources across Yanxia, these shy carp prefer to remain in shallow waters for the majority of their lives, hiding under the leaves and roots of the local aquatic plant life. During spawning season, however, they become far more aggressive─if a tranquil pond suddenly comes alive with the sound of splashing, catching carp are likely to blame.

name: Garlean Bluegill
textHtml: An invasive species once unique to Garlemald, this bluegill was introduced to the Far East during the Empire's occupation. The residents of Yanxia, desiring revenge against the Garleans in a manner that would not endanger themselves or their families, hunted down the marine invaders as a small act of rebellion, preventing their manifold multiplication.

name: Yanxian Softshell
textHtml: Yanxians prize the nutrient-rich meat of softshell turtles, historically imbibing their blood as a cure-all. Judging this to be “savage,” the Empire prohibited the practice upon the region's annexation, and it is yet unclear how this will affect Yanxian tradition long-term.

name: Pink Shrimp
textHtml: The vivid hues of this crustacean's shell are reminiscent of a cherry tree in bloom. Though other shrimp require tedious peeling and declawing before they can be eaten, the pink shrimp's carapace is pleasantly chewable. Whether its flesh is dried or baked into a savory biscuit, those who have had the pleasure of eating it claim to have glimpsed a mythical realm known only as “shrimp heaven.”

name: Sirensong Mullet
textHtml: One tale of the Sirensong Sea speaks of these “singing scourges” as harbingers that surround doomed fishing vessels ere the crew is caught in a siren's sweet serenade. Any angler who hauls one up should do so quietly, lest they drive an entire ship of seamen to hysterical tears.

name: Selkie Puffer
textHtml: Though this fish supposedly resembles a mythological being known as a selkie, few sailors have actually laid eyes upon such a creature. As such, the comparison may be thoroughly inaccurate, provoking the ire of selkies skulking in seaside taverns with every utterance.
textClean: Though this fish supposedly resembles a mythological being known as a selkie, few sailors have actually laid eyes upon such a creature. As such, the comparison may be thoroughly inaccurate, provoking the ire of selkies skulking in seaside taverns with every utterance.

name: Spear Squid
textHtml: These sharp-headed cephalopods are believed to bring good fortune to those who wield the spears they were named for─immediately, if said lancer enjoys dried squid as a snack. This perhaps explains the high demand for spear squid in Ishgard in recent years.
textClean: These sharp-headed cephalopods are believed to bring good fortune to those who wield the spears they were named for─immediately, if said lancer enjoys dried squid as a snack. This perhaps explains the high demand for spear squid in Ishgard in recent years.

name: Floating Lantern
textHtml: Weaving through the tides like a paper lantern lost in a soft summer breeze, this glowing invertebrate was once thought by local fishers to be a malevolent spirit known as a “bake-chochin,” playing tricks on unknowing passersby with its alluring lamplight. The discovery of its true nature was embarrassing for all present, save the jellyfish, which appeared unperturbed.

The discovery of its true nature was embarrassing for all present, save the jellyfish, which appeared unperturbed.

name: Rubescent Tatsunoko
textHtml: Fortunate enough to share the red-and-white coloration of the leopard prawn, these meek wavekin use the coincidence to their advantage, curling up and blending in with colonies of crustaceans to avoid conflict with other species. They may be biding their time as they grow, knowing they will one day rise upon the waves as Ruby Dragons...or not.

name: Mantle Moray
textHtml: Resembling the divine raiments worn by the Ruby Princess, this translucent blue moray sways elegantly in the currents. The more transparent the eel's scales, the higher the price it will fetch at market, and merchants make a pretty gil selling the seemingly ephemeral wavekin to collectors eager to boast of their precious find.

name: Barded Lobster
textHtml: These female lobsters are twice as large as their male counterparts, spiny lobsters, and no less fit for battle. During breeding season, pairs resemble a knight taking the field atop his faithful steed.
textClean: These female lobsters are twice as large as their male counterparts, spiny lobsters, and no less fit for battle. During breeding season, pairs resemble a knight taking the field atop his faithful steed.

name: Sanbaso
textHtml: This knifejaw's stripes create a striking resemblance to the patterned hat donned during the ceremonial sanbaso dance. Much like these performances, the fish are believed to herald peace between nations and bountiful harvests in days to come.
textClean: This knifejaw's stripes create a striking resemblance to the patterned hat donned during the ceremonial sanbaso dance. Much like these performances, the fish are believed to herald peace between nations and bountiful harvests in days to come.

name: Princess Salmon
textHtml: Unlike most other salmon species, the princess does not migrate out to sea, and lives out its entire life in familiar freshwater. Its succulent flesh was the favorite of a popular Doman princess generations past, which led to it being given its name.
textClean: Unlike most other salmon species, the princess does not migrate out to sea, and lives out its entire life in familiar freshwater. Its succulent flesh was the favorite of a popular Doman princess generations past, which led to it being given its name.

name: Calligraph
textHtml: This subspecies of lightscale is unique for having scales that look as though they had ink dripped upon them. According to Far Eastern legend, it came into being when a monk skilled at calligraphy held a brush over the One River and spilled a few drops of ink into the water.
textClean: This subspecies of lightscale is unique for having scales that look as though they had ink dripped upon them. According to Far Eastern legend, it came into being when a monk skilled at calligraphy held a brush over the One River and spilled a few drops of ink into the water.

name: Singular Shrimp
textHtml: Normally a deep green, this shrimp turns red as a plum blossom when cooked. While its flesh is somewhat tough, it boasts a singular springiness that people grow to love, and it has long been a One River specialty.
textClean: Normally a deep green, this shrimp turns red as a plum blossom when cooked. While its flesh is somewhat tough, it boasts a singular springiness that people grow to love, and it has long been a One River specialty.

name: Poet's Pipe
textHtml: A species of saltwater fish that is likened to an ocarina on account of its shape. Legend holds that, enchanted by a siren's song, a bard cast himself into the sea, and from the instrument he was clutching this fish was born.
textClean: A species of saltwater fish that is likened to an ocarina on account of its shape. Legend holds that, enchanted by a siren's song, a bard cast himself into the sea, and from the instrument he was clutching this fish was born.

name: Marine Matanga
textHtml: With its large eyes, grey body, and long nose, it is not hard to see why this shark is considered the Matanga of the sea. A folktale claims that it is the reincarnated form of a Matanga high priest who had spent years in solemn meditation.
textClean: With its large eyes, grey body, and long nose, it is not hard to see why this shark is considered the Matanga of the sea. A folktale claims that it is the reincarnated form of a Matanga high priest who had spent years in solemn meditation.

name: Hatatate
textHtml: Meaning “standard-bearer” in the Far Eastern tongue, the hatatate is identifiable by its prominent and forward-swept dorsal fin, a characteristic which earned it its name. Considered a symbol of bravery in Hingashi, it is favored among warrior families as an ornamental fish.
textClean: Meaning “standard-bearer” in the Far Eastern tongue, the hatatate is identifiable by its prominent and forward-swept dorsal fin, a characteristic which earned it its name. Considered a symbol of bravery in Hingashi, it is favored among warrior families as an ornamental fish.

name: Silent Shark
textHtml: Likened to and named for a mouse in the Far East, this shark is a swift and silent hunter that strikes before its prey is able to mount any resistance. Ranging broadly, it can be found in the Ruby Sea and all along the continental coastline.
textClean: Likened to and named for a mouse in the Far East, this shark is a swift and silent hunter that strikes before its prey is able to mount any resistance. Ranging broadly, it can be found in the Ruby Sea and all along the continental coastline.

name: Shisui Goby
textHtml: Although mainly found in the coral reefs surrounding Shisui of the Violet Tides, this variety of goby is also known to migrate widely upon the currents of the Ruby Sea. The people of Sui-no-Sato look upon them affectionately as little servants of the palace.
textClean: Although mainly found in the coral reefs surrounding Shisui of the Violet Tides, this variety of goby is also known to migrate widely upon the currents of the Ruby Sea. The people of Sui-no-Sato look upon them affectionately as little servants of the palace.

name: Violet Sentry
textHtml: Possessed of powerful jaws and dreadful fangs, this ancient crocodilian beast is said to be a guardian of Shisui of the Violet Tides. Together with the crimson sentry, a gargantuan shark, it protects the palace from would-be interlopers.
textClean: Possessed of powerful jaws and dreadful fangs, this ancient crocodilian beast is said to be a guardian of Shisui of the Violet Tides. Together with the crimson sentry, a gargantuan shark, it protects the palace from would-be interlopers.

name: Brocade Carp
textHtml: Since olden days, this carp has been prized as an ornamental fish in the Far East. Although breeders exist who specialize in the species, many exceptionally beautiful specimens can be found even in the wilds of the One River.
textClean: Since olden days, this carp has been prized as an ornamental fish in the Far East. Although breeders exist who specialize in the species, many exceptionally beautiful specimens can be found even in the wilds of the One River.

name: Yanxian Sturgeon
textHtml: Existing since prehistoric times, this fish possesses peculiar butterfly-shaped patterns upon its shark-like body─traits that have earned it the appellation “butterfly shark” in the Far East. Its flavorsome roe is enjoyed as a rare delicacy.
textClean: Existing since prehistoric times, this fish possesses peculiar butterfly-shaped patterns upon its shark-like body─traits that have earned it the appellation “butterfly shark” in the Far East. Its flavorsome roe is enjoyed as a rare delicacy.

name: Dusk Shark
textHtml: A ferocious shark that is said to haunt every sunken ship in the Sirensong Sea. Its grey body makes it appear like a spirit of the dead in the dark depths, on account of which it is feared and loathed by sailors.
textClean: A ferocious shark that is said to haunt every sunken ship in the Sirensong Sea. Its grey body makes it appear like a spirit of the dead in the dark depths, on account of which it is feared and loathed by sailors.

name: Mizuhiki
textHtml: A fish of white and crimson named for its resemblance to the rice paper cords traditionally used to wrap gifts in Hingashi. Those who manage to hook one of these decorative creatures are said to be blessed with good fortune.
textClean: A fish of white and crimson named for its resemblance to the rice paper cords traditionally used to wrap gifts in Hingashi. Those who manage to hook one of these decorative creatures are said to be blessed with good fortune.

name: Heavensent Shark
textHtml: Legend has it this fish was once a mythical tiger come from the farthest reaches of Heaven-on-High. Why such a divine beast might forgo its stripes for speckled spots─and the form of a shark, besides─remains a mystery to this day, but the wavekin is nevertheless considered an omen of bounteous catches to come.
textClean: Legend has it this fish was once a mythical tiger come from the farthest reaches of Heaven-on-High. name: Fishy Shark
textHtml: Grass sharks of this subspecies are speculated to be close cousins─or at least good friends─of the Namazu. Though its behavior may engender suspicion, the fishy shark's tendency to linger amid the vegetation of the riverbed arises from a fondness for scratching its hide against the verdure rather than more sinister motives.

name: Mermaid Scale
textHtml: This mollusk's blue and purple hues are made all the more vibrant by the aether-rich spectral waters it calls home. Though the mermaid supposed to have shed these “scales” invariably eludes them, sailors continue to fancy she is just out of sight whensoever they happen upon one.
textClean: This mollusk's blue and purple hues are made all the more vibrant by the aether-rich spectral waters it calls home. Though the mermaid supposed to have shed these “scales” invariably eludes them, sailors continue to fancy she is just out of sight whensoever they happen upon one.

name: Broadhead
textHtml: As its moniker suggests, a well-aimed broadhead darts through the water as swiftly as an arrow. No sooner do its tentacles latch onto its prey than does its powerful barbed beak sink into its victim's flesh, rendering all attempts to remove it futile.
textClean: As its moniker suggests, a well-aimed broadhead darts through the water as swiftly as an arrow. No sooner do its tentacles latch onto its prey than does its powerful barbed beak sink into its victim's flesh, rendering all attempts to remove it futile.

name: Vivid Pink Shrimp
textHtml: Aether-rich spectral currents are believed to be the secret of this shrimp's brilliant pink shade, as well as its exceedingly resilient shell. Indeed, the crustacean's carapace is so strong that shipwrights often fashion its legs and pincers into nails for their vessels.
textClean: Aether-rich spectral currents are believed to be the secret of this shrimp's brilliant pink shade, as well as its exceedingly resilient shell. Indeed, the crustacean's carapace is so strong that shipwrights often fashion its legs and pincers into nails for their vessels.

name: Sunken Coelacanth
textHtml: This ray-finned fish is highly sensitive to aetherial fluctuations in spectral currents. As fossils have surfaced the world over, researchers believe the species periodically migrates according to the aetheric density of the water.
textClean: This ray-finned fish is highly sensitive to aetherial fluctuations in spectral currents. As fossils have surfaced the world over, researchers believe the species periodically migrates according to the aetheric density of the water.

name: Siren's Sigh
textHtml: Often spotted congregating around wreckage on the ocean floor, these fish were named for the sirens thought to lure ships to their demise.
textClean: Often spotted congregating around wreckage on the ocean floor, these fish were named for the sirens thought to lure ships to their demise.

name: Black-jawed Helicoprion
textHtml: The lower jaw of this wavekin continues to grow until it folds back on itself and coils, creating a suitable tool for grinding captured prey against rocks. As one might expect, red waters are a telltale sign one has entered its feeding grounds.
textClean: The lower jaw of this wavekin continues to grow until it folds back on itself and coils, creating a suitable tool for grinding captured prey against rocks. As one might expect, red waters are a telltale sign one has entered its feeding grounds.

name: Impostopus
textHtml: By making full use of their tentacles, these cephalopods are said to be capable of impersonating any living creature. While they clearly understand the composition of their subjects, impostopodes seem to enjoy adding additional eyes to these imitations by way of their suction cups.
textClean: By making full use of their tentacles, these cephalopods are said to be capable of impersonating any living creature. While they clearly understand the composition of their subjects, impostopodes seem to enjoy adding additional eyes to these imitations by way of their suction cups.

name: Jade Mantis Shrimp
textHtml: Making its home in the Sea of Jade, this species of crustacean is well known for the breathtaking green of its carapace─a color with which it seems rather singularly taken in spite of its ability to perceive myriad hues. To maintain the desired coloration, individuals will migrate along spectral currents upon coming of age, in search of the perfect environment.
textClean: Making its home in the Sea of Jade, this species of crustacean is well known for the breathtaking green of its carapace─a color with which it seems rather singularly taken in spite of its ability to perceive myriad hues. name: Nymeia's Wheel
textHtml: Legends say that each time the goddess Nymeia drops a spinning wheel, it falls from the heavens and becomes a shell for one of these enormous tortoises. The sheer number of these wavekin suggests that even the Twelve are fallible.
textClean: Legends say that each time the goddess Nymeia drops a spinning wheel, it falls from the heavens and becomes a shell for one of these enormous tortoises. The sheer number of these wavekin suggests that even the Twelve are fallible.

name: Snapping Koban
textHtml: Spectral currents make the blue skin of this wavekin almost transparent, causing its yellow fins and mouth to appear as coins floating just under the ocean's surface. Many a greedy sailor has fallen overboard after reaching out a little too far over the bulwark.
textClean: Spectral currents make the blue skin of this wavekin almost transparent, causing its yellow fins and mouth to appear as coins floating just under the ocean's surface. Many a greedy sailor has fallen overboard after reaching out a little too far over the bulwark.

name: Silkweft Prawn
textHtml: These wavekin are named for the fine material of the nets used to catch them. Connoisseurs insist that any other netting would ruin the prawn's delicate flesh, while others claim it is merely a pretext to sell the crustacean at an inflated price.
textClean: These wavekin are named for the fine material of the nets used to catch them. Connoisseurs insist that any other netting would ruin the prawn's delicate flesh, while others claim it is merely a pretext to sell the crustacean at an inflated price.

name: Stingfin Trevally
textHtml: The striking blue fins of this wavekin contain a venom made deadly by the aetherial concentration of spectral currents. A skilled chef can cut out the stingfin's meat without causing contamination, although few consider the reward to be worth the risk.
textClean: The striking blue fins of this wavekin contain a venom made deadly by the aetherial concentration of spectral currents. A skilled chef can cut out the stingfin's meat without causing contamination, although few consider the reward to be worth the risk.

name: Swordtip Squid
textHtml: The sleek, clear body of this wavekin has inspired countless swordsmiths during their seaborne journeys. Opinions are divided on whether the dried swordtip squid or dried spear squid is tastier, with one's martial background apparently being the main indicator of preference.
textClean: The sleek, clear body of this wavekin has inspired countless swordsmiths during their seaborne journeys. Opinions are divided on whether the dried swordtip squid or dried spear squid is tastier, with one's martial background apparently being the main indicator of preference.

name: Mailfish
textHtml: This wavekin's silver scales are reminiscent of chainmail. It swims with its head bowed, and this mannerism has made it popular as a symbol of the Far East's hospitable culture.
textClean: This wavekin's silver scales are reminiscent of chainmail. It swims with its head bowed, and this mannerism has made it popular as a symbol of the Far East's hospitable culture.

name: Idaten's Bolt
textHtml: These fish dart through the water at blinding speed that, per Far Eastern sailors, can only be the will of the kami. Spectral currents sometimes propel them with such force that they skip out of water, flying through the air at velocities to rival those of passing airships.
textClean: These fish dart through the water at blinding speed that, per Far Eastern sailors, can only be the will of the kami. Spectral currents sometimes propel them with such force that they skip out of water, flying through the air at velocities to rival those of passing airships.

name: Maelstrom Turban
textHtml: Feasting upon the nutrients replete in spectral currents, these shelled wavekin grow to prodigious sizes. In the folklore of Hingashi are tales of gale winds caused by the shell's unique structure, and many still believe the maelstrom turban to be the source of inclement weather in the region.
textClean: Feasting upon the nutrients replete in spectral currents, these shelled wavekin grow to prodigious sizes. In the folklore of Hingashi are tales of gale winds caused by the shell's unique structure, and many still believe the maelstrom turban to be the source of inclement weather in the region.

name: Shoshitsuki
textHtml: The speed of these enormous sharks has seen them named for the demons that fleet-footed Idaten pursued across the firmament. A single fearsome pod can hold dominion over a territory stretching from the Ruby Sea to Kugane.
textClean: The speed of these enormous sharks has seen them named for the demons that fleet-footed Idaten pursued across the firmament. A single fearsome pod can hold dominion over a territory stretching from the Ruby Sea to Kugane.

name: Spadefish
textHtml: One legend tells of a young farmer who, yearning for the excitement of city life, cast his spade into a nearby canal. The spade turned into a fish which then swam the long journey to Kugane, although whether the farmer followed suit differs depending on the storyteller's intended moral.
textClean: One legend tells of a young farmer who, yearning for the excitement of city life, cast his spade into a nearby canal. The spade turned into a fish which then swam the long journey to Kugane, although whether the farmer followed suit differs depending on the storyteller's intended moral.

name: Fleeting Squid
textHtml: This wavekin's body is shaped like a leaf, and its color changes to adapt to its environment. A school of fleeting squid swimming through a spectral current looks like an upside down forest, inviting one to become lost among its sunken paths.
textClean: This wavekin's body is shaped like a leaf, and its color changes to adapt to its environment. A school of fleeting squid swimming through a spectral current looks like an upside down forest, inviting one to become lost among its sunken paths.

name: Bowbarb Lobster
textHtml: Characterized by its long whiskers, a male bowbarb lobster placed upon its back and viewed from exactly the right angle resembles a bowman taking aim.
textClean: Characterized by its long whiskers, a male bowbarb lobster placed upon its back and viewed from exactly the right angle resembles a bowman taking aim.

name: Pitch Pickle
textHtml: This rare species of sea pickle was a favorite of Hingan nobility in generations past. As was the fashion at the time, they preferred to dye their teeth black, and a single pitch pickle was a swift means to a stygian smile.
textClean: This rare species of sea pickle was a favorite of Hingan nobility in generations past. As was the fashion at the time, they preferred to dye their teeth black, and a single pitch pickle was a swift means to a stygian smile.

name: Senbei Octopus
textHtml: When fished from the sea, this octopus folds its body into a shape not unlike the round crackers popular in the Far East. As an inevitable consequence, many a sailor has been caught by surprise when their late-night snack transformed into a ball of writhing tentacles.
textClean: When fished from the sea, this octopus folds its body into a shape not unlike the round crackers popular in the Far East. As an inevitable consequence, many a sailor has been caught by surprise when their late-night snack transformed into a ball of writhing tentacles.

name: Tentacle Thresher
textHtml: Although this species of shark could have its pick of the ocean's bounty, it seems strangely fixated on hunting octopodes. Only in extreme states of hunger has a specimen been observed eating anything else, and even then, only enough to last until the next tentacled morsel comes along.
textClean: Although this species of shark could have its pick of the ocean's bounty, it seems strangely fixated on hunting octopodes. Only in extreme states of hunger has a specimen been observed eating anything else, and even then, only enough to last until the next tentacled morsel comes along.

name: Bekko Rockhugger
textHtml: The spread of these wavekin to various regions is credited to spectral currents, which are the only force strong enough to wrest them from their rocky homes. Their tendency to settle on the ocean floor has earned them the favor of the Kojin, who sense a kindred spirit in the fish.
textClean: The spread of these wavekin to various regions is credited to spectral currents, which are the only force strong enough to wrest them from their rocky homes. Their tendency to settle on the ocean floor has earned them the favor of the Kojin, who sense a kindred spirit in the fish.

name: Yellow Iris
textHtml: The delicate yellow scales of this fish belie its invasive nature, and many an ecosystem has been disrupted by the yellow iris's arrival on currents from afar. Sailors know to batten down the hatches upon sighting a school of them, for they invariably carry rough seas in their wake.
textClean: The delicate yellow scales of this fish belie its invasive nature, and many an ecosystem has been disrupted by the yellow iris's arrival on currents from afar. Sailors know to batten down the hatches upon sighting a school of them, for they invariably carry rough seas in their wake.

name: Crimson Sentry
textHtml: One of the two guardians of Shisui of the Violet Tides, this sentry has many times stained the sea red with the blood of those foolish enough to encroach upon the sacred halls.
textClean: One of the two guardians of Shisui of the Violet Tides, this sentry has many times stained the sea red with the blood of those foolish enough to encroach upon the sacred halls.

name: Flying Squid
textHtml: Perhaps due to spending less time in the ocean than its seabound cousins, flying squid is considered inferior in flavor to other varieties of dried squid. Due to its low price and high availability, however, it is a staple among the commonfolk.
textClean: Perhaps due to spending less time in the ocean than its seabound cousins, flying squid is considered inferior in flavor to other varieties of dried squid. Due to its low price and high availability, however, it is a staple among the commonfolk.

name: Gensui Shrimp
textHtml: As this shrimp ages, its body becomes a deep shade of green. It is reminiscent of a legend of the Gensui Chain about a hermit whose skin took on the hue of the sweeping hills he lived among, leading some locals to call the species “hermits”─to the discomfit of foreign diners.
textClean: As this shrimp ages, its body becomes a deep shade of green. It is reminiscent of a legend of the Gensui Chain about a hermit whose skin took on the hue of the sweeping hills he lived among, leading some locals to call the species “hermits”─to the discomfit of foreign diners.

name: Yato-no-kami
textHtml: Yanxian legend tells of an ancient demon that once haunted the region, siphoning its nutrients and preventing the people from cultivating their land. A group of brave monks risked life and limb to seal it away and cast it into a spectral current, consigning it to a life of eternal wandering.

A group of brave monks risked life and limb to seal it away and cast it into a spectral current, consigning it to a life of eternal wandering.

name: Heron's Eel
textHtml: Eels of the Heron's Way often grow too large to sustain themselves on their environment's meager offerings, and make their way to the One River in search of a feast befitting their station. This has led to their consumption as a delicacy, with merchants seeing a reflection of their own journey in the eel's, though the flavor is naught to write home about.

name: Crowshadow Mussel
textHtml: The jet black shell of this bivalve mollusk can grow up to a fulm in length, giving it the appearance of a crow spreading its wings under the waves. The inside of the shell, however, is a dazzling pearly white.
textClean: The jet black shell of this bivalve mollusk can grow up to a fulm in length, giving it the appearance of a crow spreading its wings under the waves. The inside of the shell, however, is a dazzling pearly white.

name: Yanxian Goby
textHtml: This species of goby has migrated south from the Azim Steppe. The aether-rich spectral currents are their domain, and they swim through the turbulent waters without challenge.
textClean: This species of goby has migrated south from the Azim Steppe. The aether-rich spectral currents are their domain, and they swim through the turbulent waters without challenge.

name: Iridescent Trout
textHtml: Spectral currents have given this wavekin's scales a faint iridescence. They are highly valued by artisans of the Far East, with the most radiant scales fetching a high price at auction.
textClean: Spectral currents have given this wavekin's scales a faint iridescence. They are highly valued by artisans of the Far East, with the most radiant scales fetching a high price at auction.

name: Un-Namazu
textHtml: This unremarkable catfish is believed to have once been a Namazu so indolent that he reversed nature's course, regressing into the primitive form of his ancestors. Let this be a warning to any Namazu that would lie listlessly in his jar while there is work to be done, yes, yes.
textClean: This unremarkable catfish is believed to have once been a Namazu so indolent that he reversed nature's course, regressing into the primitive form of his ancestors. Let this be a warning to any Namazu that would lie listlessly in his jar while there is work to be done, yes, yes.

name: Gakugyo
textHtml: According to a Far Eastern faerie tale, a white rabbit from the moon once placed this wavekin into the One River and utilized its sprawling form as a bridge. Given the gakugyo's rancorous demeanor, any such meeting seems more likely to result in the rabbit's being devoured whole, but perhaps it was of milder temperament before being thoroughly trod upon by hippity-hoppity feet.

name: Ginrin Goshiki
textHtml: Boasting scales of deep vermilion and silver, this paragon among carp makes its abode within spectral currents, thus its vivid coloration. From the water's surface, the wavekin reflects light much like a glimmering gold ingot, and as a result, many an unknowing sailor has fallen overboard in pursuit of false riches.

name: Spectral Coelacanth
textHtml: Its species having survived for a number of Astral Eras with strikingly few evolutionary gains, this particular coelacanth apparently decided it was high time for a change. After many a moon spent swimming the spectral currents, it has achieved partially crystalline scales and a glorious blue glow.
textClean: Its species having survived for a number of Astral Eras with strikingly few evolutionary gains, this particular coelacanth apparently decided it was high time for a change. After many a moon spent swimming the spectral currents, it has achieved partially crystalline scales and a glorious blue glow.

name: Spectral Wrasse
textHtml: Ichthyologists have spent many sleepless nights studying the behaviors of the spectral wrasse, unable to understand what drives them to chase spectral currents─if, indeed, extant specimens did not end up there by accident. The single paper published on the subject, entitled “No Wrasse for the Wicked,” has been responsible for several leaving the profession entirely.

name: Spectral Snake Eel
textHtml: While the majority of snake eels tend to lurk under the sands and await the coming of their prey, these creatures─likely realizing that such tactics are not quite as effective when one has sparkling blue scales─have been spotted near the water's surface, blending in with the azure surf to catch their victims unawares.

name: Spectral Kotsu Zetsu
textHtml: When the spectral currents affect a kotsu zetsu, its bone-like tongue takes on the same glow as its scales. These appendages are highly valued by local artisans, who utilize special tools to clean and carve them into luminous pendants and finery.
textClean: When the spectral currents affect a kotsu zetsu, its bone-like tongue takes on the same glow as its scales. These appendages are highly valued by local artisans, who utilize special tools to clean and carve them into luminous pendants and finery.

name: Taniwha
textHtml: Though “taniwha” is oft translated from the language of the south sea isles as merely “dangerous shark,” the slumbering creatures' backs are said to support many of the islands themselves. Accordingly, legend has it that their modern descendants make yearly migrations to the southern seas to ensure that their ancestors are well treated.

name: Glass Dragon
textHtml: Said to have ruled the eastern seas alongside the Ruby Dragon, this living legend sports a set of silvery scales that shimmer in the sun. Some historians go so far as to claim it an auspice who clashed mightily with Seiryu in ages past.
textClean: Said to have ruled the eastern seas alongside the Ruby Dragon, this living legend sports a set of silvery scales that shimmer in the sun. Some historians go so far as to claim it an auspice who clashed mightily with Seiryu in ages past.

name: Hells' Claw
textHtml: This formidable king of the Crab Pots dons an armored shell of volcanic rock to protect itself against would-be predators. While this defense mechanism has proven successful, the sweltering heat of its once-molten carapace would cook the crustacean from the inside out had it not made a habit of launching itself into the cool depths of the Ruby Sea.

name: Jewel of Plum Spring
textHtml: Wanting nothing more than to swim in the limpid waters it had long admired from afar, a wise old tree of Plum Spring is said to have shaped one of its knots into this flowering turtle. Though the plum blossoms are often submerged when the creature dives, their petals miraculously show no signs of wear.

name: The Fury's Aegis
textHtml: For reasons as of yet unknown, Sharlayan naturalists have recently been inundated by a veritable mountain of inquiries from anonymous adventurers asking why this species of shrimp does not have the ability to transform into a shrimp-sized sword and fire shrimp-sized beams of rime. Perplexed by the specificity of the question, they have been unable to give a satisfactory answer.

name: Gold Dustfish
textHtml: Such is the beauty of this creature's aurulent scales that it has been likened to a treasure once lost by the Nabaath royal family to the dunes of Amh Araeng.
textClean: Such is the beauty of this creature's aurulent scales that it has been likened to a treasure once lost by the Nabaath royal family to the dunes of Amh Araeng.

name: Forgiven Melancholy
textHtml: Whether this entity is an albino fish or a sin eater masquerading as one has long been a matter of debate among Crystarium naturalists. Recent testimony from former inhabitants of the Derelicts, however, may at last tip the scales─evidently, the creature tastes uncannily similar to meol.

name: Oil Slick
textHtml: The scales of this creature glisten with a cacophony of colors like unto the surface of gleaming oil─a useful form of camouflage amidst the iridescent sheen of the iron-rich plunge basin it calls home.
textClean: The scales of this creature glisten with a cacophony of colors like unto the surface of gleaming oil─a useful form of camouflage amidst the iridescent sheen of the iron-rich plunge basin it calls home.

name: Gonzalo's Grace
textHtml: According to Kholusian legend, this brightly colored echinoderm once served a princely sort who found himself stranded far out to sea. After a series of trials involving literacy, magic, and a rather abrupt masque, Gonzalo returned his liege to his rightful place and vanished amongst the tides, never to be seen again─until an adventurer from another world unknowingly reeled him in.

name: Circuit Tilapia
textHtml: Naturally lengthy lifespans make these wavekin ideal subjects for long-term monitoring. They are thus the indispensable companions of Sharlayan researchers involved in the study and maintenance of water quality, who at this point have named quite a number with appellations befitting their individual countenances.
textClean: Naturally lengthy lifespans make these wavekin ideal subjects for long-term monitoring. They are thus the indispensable companions of Sharlayan researchers involved in the study and maintenance of water quality, who at this point have named quite a number with appellations befitting their individual countenances.

name: Durdina Fish
textHtml: Protective of their underwater kingdoms as Paksa fish may be, none have yet been known to defy the authority of this particular specimen. Thus was she named for the legendary queen Durdina, the only one to whom Paksa ever bowed.
textClean: Protective of their underwater kingdoms as Paksa fish may be, none have yet been known to defy the authority of this particular specimen. Thus was she named for the legendary queen Durdina, the only one to whom Paksa ever bowed.

name: Mayaman
textHtml: No few monks went missing in the bygone days when solitary ablutions in the Font of Maya were a popular form of devotion. Locals have come to offer their prayers for these wayward souls to the Mayaman─presumably while keeping a respectful distance from this caiman grown large on the font's nutritional boons.
textClean: No few monks went missing in the bygone days when solitary ablutions in the Font of Maya were a popular form of devotion. Locals have come to offer their prayers for these wayward souls to the Mayaman─presumably while keeping a respectful distance from this caiman grown large on the font's nutritional boons.

name: Chlorophos Deathworm
textHtml: Per Loporrit sources, little can compare to the experience of gazing into silent subterranean waters to see this massive, writhing worm casting a sickly glow. They likely have the sunken spores of proximal fungi to thank for the unique experience, though the scientific community has been slow to verify this hypothesis.
textClean: Per Loporrit sources, little can compare to the experience of gazing into silent subterranean waters to see this massive, writhing worm casting a sickly glow. They likely have the sunken spores of proximal fungi to thank for the unique experience, though the scientific community has been slow to verify this hypothesis.

name: Starscale Ephemeris
textHtml: Due to its particular sensitivity to even the most minor magnetic fluctuations, this starscale charts its school's orbit with the utmost precision. Its fellows are only too eager to follow, for the slightest deviation might mean their end.
textClean: Due to its particular sensitivity to even the most minor magnetic fluctuations, this starscale charts its school's orbit with the utmost precision. Its fellows are only too eager to follow, for the slightest deviation might mean their end.

name: E.B.E.-852738
textHtml: If we take at face value the assertion that the E.B.E.-9318s are observational appendages of extra-dimensional entities, then perhaps it follows that this anomaly, with its unusually large and unblinking “eye,” is of even greater use in observing the phenomena of our cosmos. Or perhaps this theory, too, reflects our terrifyingly limited perspective.
textClean: If we take at face value the assertion that the E.B.E.-9318s are observational appendages of extra-dimensional entities, then perhaps it follows that this anomaly, with its unusually large and unblinking “eye,” is of even greater use in observing the phenomena of our cosmos. Or perhaps this theory, too, reflects our terrifyingly limited perspective.

name: Ossicula
textHtml: Replete with tiny bones equally visible whether the specimen is fresh or has lain desiccated waiting for a researcher to “get round to it” for moons, this fish also contains nutrients that may help rebuild cartilage, promising another experimental salvo in science's ceaseless war against lower back pain.
textClean: Replete with tiny bones equally visible whether the specimen is fresh or has lain desiccated waiting for a researcher to “get round to it” for moons, this fish also contains nutrients that may help rebuild cartilage, promising another experimental salvo in science's ceaseless war against lower back pain.

name: Kitty Herring
textHtml: Toothsome and high in protein, this herring is one of the few wavekin guaranteed to satisfy the refined palates of Garlemald's domesticated cats─once it has been prepared for convenient consumption by doting hands. Needless to say, such strategies have figured prominently in the reconstruction effort.
textClean: Toothsome and high in protein, this herring is one of the few wavekin guaranteed to satisfy the refined palates of Garlemald's domesticated cats─once it has been prepared for convenient consumption by doting hands. Needless to say, such strategies have figured prominently in the reconstruction effort.

name: Sarikuyruk
textHtml: Named for the saffron shading of its tail, this nutritious wavekin is considered an effective bulwark against progressive vision loss. Though this claim has been verified by the Faculty of Medicine, experts emphasize that the consumption of great quantities will not result in powers of sight exceeding typical mortal limits.
textClean: Named for the saffron shading of its tail, this nutritious wavekin is considered an effective bulwark against progressive vision loss. Though this claim has been verified by the Faculty of Medicine, experts emphasize that the consumption of great quantities will not result in powers of sight exceeding typical mortal limits.

name: Stargilt Lobster
textHtml: Despite its resemblance to gold leaf, the coating on a stargilt lobster's carapace serves the practical purpose of protection amidst the odd aetherial eddies of its habitat. Should one boil the creature like a common lobster, the coating will dissolve and lend the flesh a complex flavor─as will the knowledge of contributing to the extinction of a dead star's few survivors.

name: Deadwood Shadow
textHtml: This wavekin's ebon scales are reminiscent of the Greatwood's subaquatic sentinels. It drifts amongst the lightless depths like a submerged branch, swiftly sinking its teeth into the flesh of unsuspecting prey.
textClean: This wavekin's ebon scales are reminiscent of the Greatwood's subaquatic sentinels. It drifts amongst the lightless depths like a submerged branch, swiftly sinking its teeth into the flesh of unsuspecting prey.

name: Ronkan Bullion
textHtml: Some assert that this hulking fish is one of the lost treasures of Ronka, transformed into a living creature by ancient magicks. Regardless of the tale's veracity, it is unlikely that this wavekin could return to its original form by the hands of an amateur─only descendants of Ronkan priests can perform the necessary rites to do so.
textClean: Some assert that this hulking fish is one of the lost treasures of Ronka, transformed into a living creature by ancient magicks. name: Golding
textHtml: The flat, golden scales of this fish resemble a scattering of gold coins from the water's surface. Those greedy few who mistake it as such, however, will find themselves dragged into the depths before they can claim the false fortune as their own.
textClean: The flat, golden scales of this fish resemble a scattering of gold coins from the water's surface. Those greedy few who mistake it as such, however, will find themselves dragged into the depths before they can claim the false fortune as their own.

name: Little Bounty
textHtml: On a visit to Il Mheg, the Crystal Exarch spotted a fish whose cerulean hues resembled the seas of his homeland. Fascinated by his tale, the people of the Crystarium began to refer to this wavekin as the little Bounty, that they might one day gaze upon the creature for themselves and reminisce on the vivid colors of their long-lost seas.
textClean: On a visit to Il Mheg, the Crystal Exarch spotted a fish whose cerulean hues resembled the seas of his homeland. name: Saint Fathric's Face
textHtml: Saint Fathric was once a household name in the Kingdom of Voeburt, famed for his abnormally strict and lengthy acts of penance. Though the kingdom he served lies in ruins, his name lives on through this wavekin, whose rock-solid head remains as unbreakable as the saint's stubborn will.
textClean: Saint Fathric was once a household name in the Kingdom of Voeburt, famed for his abnormally strict and lengthy acts of penance. Though the kingdom he served lies in ruins, his name lives on through this wavekin, whose rock-solid head remains as unbreakable as the saint's stubborn will.

name: Hyphalosaurus
textHtml: Aptly named the “submerged lizard,” this lanky specimen utilizes its flat, elongated tail as a fin, allowing it to glide through the freshwater depths with relative ease.
textClean: Aptly named the “submerged lizard,” this lanky specimen utilizes its flat, elongated tail as a fin, allowing it to glide through the freshwater depths with relative ease.

name: Gharlichthys
textHtml: Professor Gharl─a Studium scholar of both Near and Far Eastern ancestry─happened upon this whalelike wavekin while conducting a survey of marine life populations in Thavnair. Overjoyed to discover such an ancient species so close to home, the Auri academic proudly began to refer to the creature as “Gharl's fish.”
textClean: Professor Gharl─a Studium scholar of both Near and Far Eastern ancestry─happened upon this whalelike wavekin while conducting a survey of marine life populations in Thavnair. name: Snowy Parexus
textHtml: This wavekin was born with more evolutionary boons than most─the aetheric crystallizations on its scales serve as a means of camouflage, while the spiny protrusions from its fins prevent would-be predators from devouring it in one fell bite.
textClean: This wavekin was born with more evolutionary boons than most─the aetheric crystallizations on its scales serve as a means of camouflage, while the spiny protrusions from its fins prevent would-be predators from devouring it in one fell bite.

name: Furcacauda
textHtml: A resourceful ancient once coined the concept for a flat-tailed wavekin whose bones could be crafted into fine tableware. Fish bones did not make for aesthetically pleasing saucers, however, and the plan was eventually abandoned.
textClean: A resourceful ancient once coined the concept for a flat-tailed wavekin whose bones could be crafted into fine tableware. Fish bones did not make for aesthetically pleasing saucers, however, and the plan was eventually abandoned.

name: Lopoceras Elegans
textHtml: When the Loporrits came across this abnormally winding cephalopod, its beauteous spirals reminded them of a long, floppy ear. Though the lunar residents could not come to a consensus on how such an ear could be so long and floppy, they were nevertheless impressed, and would unanimously agree to name the creature an honorary Loporrit.
textClean: When the Loporrits came across this abnormally winding cephalopod, its beauteous spirals reminded them of a long, floppy ear. name: Sidereal Whale
textHtml: Recent theories on the subject of this cosmic wavekin suggest it to be the inspiration for the lunar whale─the starfaring airship of Mysidian myth.
textClean: Recent theories on the subject of this cosmic wavekin suggest it to be the inspiration for the lunar whale─the starfaring airship of Mysidian myth.

name: Mosquito Fish
textHtml: Historically, this wavekin was introduced to various locales as a means of pest control─a cunning way of leveraging its enduring appetite for infuriating insects. To this day, populations still inhabit the waterways of Tuliyollal itself.
textClean: Historically, this wavekin was introduced to various locales as a means of pest control─a cunning way of leveraging its enduring appetite for infuriating insects. To this day, populations still inhabit the waterways of Tuliyollal itself.

name: Pel Frog
textHtml: Easily mistaken for golden ornaments, these dainty amphibians are revered by the Pelupelu as harbingers of financial success. Indeed, some devotees keep the frogs as pets in small pots, hoping to profit from their alleged powers.
textClean: Easily mistaken for golden ornaments, these dainty amphibians are revered by the Pelupelu as harbingers of financial success. Indeed, some devotees keep the frogs as pets in small pots, hoping to profit from their alleged powers.

name: Petticoat Tetra
textHtml: With dull silver scales and dark frilly fins, this species of tetra has an understated elegance. Appearances can be deceptive, however─simply ask any of the countless Tuliyollan children who've been bitten by this surprisingly belligerent wavekin.
textClean: With dull silver scales and dark frilly fins, this species of tetra has an understated elegance. Appearances can be deceptive, however─simply ask any of the countless Tuliyollan children who've been bitten by this surprisingly belligerent wavekin.

name: Reasonscale Silverside
textHtml: When Tuliyollal's population began to boom, the Head of Reason sought to preempt future shortages by introducing this foreign species as a source of food. Fortunately for the growing city and its hungry residents, the fish soon became established in their new environment.
textClean: When Tuliyollal's population began to boom, the Head of Reason sought to preempt future shortages by introducing this foreign species as a source of food. Fortunately for the growing city and its hungry residents, the fish soon became established in their new environment.

name: Stardust Shrimp
textHtml: This delicious native of the Stardust Sea is a popular staple. In Tuliyollal, these shrimp are deep-fried before being slathered in all manner of rich, fragrant sauces.
textClean: This delicious native of the Stardust Sea is a popular staple. In Tuliyollal, these shrimp are deep-fried before being slathered in all manner of rich, fragrant sauces.

name: Shallows Sot
textHtml: Named after its alleged resemblance to the red face of an inveterate drunkard, the colloquialism has all but superseded the wavekin's original Yok Huy name. The fish itself seems unperturbed by the unflattering comparisons.
textClean: Named after its alleged resemblance to the red face of an inveterate drunkard, the colloquialism has all but superseded the wavekin's original Yok Huy name. The fish itself seems unperturbed by the unflattering comparisons.

name: Ghostfish
textHtml: The silver scales of this saltwater fish are highly reflective, endowing it with the illusion of transparency. Known to be inquisitive, it is often seen swimming to the surface when people are present.
textClean: The silver scales of this saltwater fish are highly reflective, endowing it with the illusion of transparency. Known to be inquisitive, it is often seen swimming to the surface when people are present.

name: Permit
textHtml: This cautious wavekin's broad silver body is speckled with inky black spots. The slightest hint of a predator is enough to send this timid specimen darting off to the relative safety of a rocky crevasse or other shaded spot.
textClean: This cautious wavekin's broad silver body is speckled with inky black spots. The slightest hint of a predator is enough to send this timid specimen darting off to the relative safety of a rocky crevasse or other shaded spot.

name: Floating Fife
textHtml: Occasionally seen swimming with its head pointed toward the seabed, this slender wavekin bears a remarkable resemblance to its namesake. Keen-eyed observers will note that it features on the insignia of the Landsguard fife and drum corps.
textClean: Occasionally seen swimming with its head pointed toward the seabed, this slender wavekin bears a remarkable resemblance to its namesake. Keen-eyed observers will note that it features on the insignia of the Landsguard fife and drum corps.

name: Blue Purse
textHtml: The fine, gold-rimmed scales of this wavekin almost look like overlapping coins, bringing to mind a bulging purse filled with riches.
textClean: The fine, gold-rimmed scales of this wavekin almost look like overlapping coins, bringing to mind a bulging purse filled with riches.

name: Goldfin Cavalli
textHtml: The golden fins of this saltwater fish are often likened to the honed tip of a halberd. Seen as protectors of the capital's harbor, these wavekin are venerated by Tuliyollan sailors.
textClean: The golden fins of this saltwater fish are often likened to the honed tip of a halberd. Seen as protectors of the capital's harbor, these wavekin are venerated by Tuliyollan sailors.

name: Sea Alpaca
textHtml: These wavekin favor the briniest waters, inhabiting inland lakes that were once contiguous with the ocean. Naturalists saw fit to name them for the Pelupelu's popular pack animal─though they are nowhere near as fuzzy as their mammalian counterparts.
textClean: These wavekin favor the briniest waters, inhabiting inland lakes that were once contiguous with the ocean. Naturalists saw fit to name them for the Pelupelu's popular pack animal─though they are nowhere near as fuzzy as their mammalian counterparts.

name: Marbled Hatchetfish
textHtml: The Yok Huy tell of a mighty warrior of yore who, beset by grief, cast down their axe. The weapon transformed into a majestic wavekin bearing marbled scales, its intricate patterns a manifestation of the warrior's agony.
textClean: The Yok Huy tell of a mighty warrior of yore who, beset by grief, cast down their axe. The weapon transformed into a majestic wavekin bearing marbled scales, its intricate patterns a manifestation of the warrior's agony.

name: Starsnipper
textHtml: When night falls, this tiny crustacean scuttles forth, brandishing its pincers, seemingly trying to snip at the stars reflected on the water's surface. One can only begin to fathom what drove the crab to its unceasing battle with the firmament.
textClean: When night falls, this tiny crustacean scuttles forth, brandishing its pincers, seemingly trying to snip at the stars reflected on the water's surface. One can only begin to fathom what drove the crab to its unceasing battle with the firmament.

name: Urqotrout
textHtml: As it inhabits a highly concentrated brine, this wavekin boasts naturally salty flesh. It is prized by the Yok Huy for being effectively pre-seasoned, and thereby delightfully simple to prepare.
textClean: As it inhabits a highly concentrated brine, this wavekin boasts naturally salty flesh. It is prized by the Yok Huy for being effectively pre-seasoned, and thereby delightfully simple to prepare.

name: Yok Huy Stonecutter
textHtml: This bladelike fish is said to resemble the implements used by Yok Huy quarry workers. Individuals with ragged fins are sarcastically likened to old tools sorely in need of a good honing.
textClean: This bladelike fish is said to resemble the implements used by Yok Huy quarry workers. Individuals with ragged fins are sarcastically likened to old tools sorely in need of a good honing.

name: Chirwagur Loach
textHtml: A slender cylindrical fish covered head to tail with fine grey scales. Already small, this wavekin shrinks even further when cooked whole, often leaving naught but salt-encrusted skin.
textClean: A slender cylindrical fish covered head to tail with fine grey scales. Already small, this wavekin shrinks even further when cooked whole, often leaving naught but salt-encrusted skin.

name: Alright Alright Alright
textHtml: Neither phonetically accurate to its indigenous appellation nor comprehensible in any way, this fish's name illustrates the proud ignorance that characterized many early visits to the “New World.” Had he listened well enough to learn of the wavekin's ability to swim only to the left, the Eorzean naturalist who “discovered” it would perhaps have chosen differently.
textClean: Neither phonetically accurate to its indigenous appellation nor comprehensible in any way, this fish's name illustrates the proud ignorance that characterized many early visits to the “New World.” Had he listened well enough to learn of the wavekin's ability to swim only to the left, the Eorzean naturalist who “discovered” it would perhaps have chosen differently.

name: Zorlortor
textHtml: Said to have been named after a cowardly Yok Huy, this timid silver amphibian is often seen paddling around saltwater pools. One can only imagine the burning shame Zorlortor must have felt being associated with such a creature.
textClean: Said to have been named after a cowardly Yok Huy, this timid silver amphibian is often seen paddling around saltwater pools. One can only imagine the burning shame Zorlortor must have felt being associated with such a creature.

name: Shooting Starscale
textHtml: Folklore describes this wavekin as the remnant of a fallen star come to life, from an era in which the skies above Tural blazed with meteor showers. Indeed, when seen glinting in the water on a moonlit night, it is easily confused for the reflection of a comet arcing across the heavens.
textClean: Folklore describes this wavekin as the remnant of a fallen star come to life, from an era in which the skies above Tural blazed with meteor showers. Indeed, when seen glinting in the water on a moonlit night, it is easily confused for the reflection of a comet arcing across the heavens.

name: First Feastfish
textHtml: According to legend, a member of this species was the very first morsel consumed by the ancient Yok Huy progenitor. Given this wavekin's high nutritional value, one can commend the giant's decision after emerging─presumably famished─from the primordial lake.
textClean: According to legend, a member of this species was the very first morsel consumed by the ancient Yok Huy progenitor. Given this wavekin's high nutritional value, one can commend the giant's decision after emerging─presumably famished─from the primordial lake.

name: Urqofrog
textHtml: Endemic to Karvarhur the First, on average, these amphibians grow no larger than a single handspan. Girthier specimens have been observed, however─some bulking up to be wider than the waist of a Pelupelu. Admittedly, this is hardly an awe-inspiring metric.
textClean: Endemic to Karvarhur the First, on average, these amphibians grow no larger than a single handspan. Girthier specimens have been observed, however─some bulking up to be wider than the waist of a Pelupelu. Admittedly, this is hardly an awe-inspiring metric.

name: Zeh Tortoh
textHtml: Roughly translated, the Yok Huy name of this wavekin means “fish of never-ending blooms.” A fitting name for a creature bearing such a close resemblance to a delicate petal.
textClean: Roughly translated, the Yok Huy name of this wavekin means “fish of never-ending blooms.” A fitting name for a creature bearing such a close resemblance to a delicate petal.

name: Morsel Trout
textHtml: This fish's name has origins in both the Pelupelu and Yok Huy languages, respectively referred to as “the filling fish” and “the fish of scant flesh.” The modern appellation attempts to strike a balance between the conflicting perspectives.
textClean: This fish's name has origins in both the Pelupelu and Yok Huy languages, respectively referred to as “the filling fish” and “the fish of scant flesh.” The modern appellation attempts to strike a balance between the conflicting perspectives.

name: Deepwarden
textHtml: This looming, ancient wavekin has circled the depths of Karvarhur the First since time immemorial, watching on as generations of Yok Huy have prospered and fallen.
textClean: This looming, ancient wavekin has circled the depths of Karvarhur the First since time immemorial, watching on as generations of Yok Huy have prospered and fallen.

name: Kozama'uka Skipper
textHtml: This agile fish leaps between waterways with its broad, sail-like fins, constantly on the hunt for new sources of insect prey─or perhaps a mere change of scenery.
textClean: This agile fish leaps between waterways with its broad, sail-like fins, constantly on the hunt for new sources of insect prey─or perhaps a mere change of scenery.

name: Bopo'u Sleeper
textHtml: Upon encountering this fish submerged in the mud, novice naturalists may mistake its inactivity for drowsiness. In actual fact, this wavekin has perfected the art of remaining perfectly still─waiting for hapless prey to come to it.
textClean: Upon encountering this fish submerged in the mud, novice naturalists may mistake its inactivity for drowsiness. In actual fact, this wavekin has perfected the art of remaining perfectly still─waiting for hapless prey to come to it.

name: Poison Dyefrog
textHtml: Although the toxins this tiny frog secretes are deadly, the Hanuhanu have used the substance to dye their plumage for generations.
textClean: Although the toxins this tiny frog secretes are deadly, the Hanuhanu have used the substance to dye their plumage for generations.

name: Pleated Matamata
textHtml: Named for the pleated protrusions adorning its shell, this gentle turtle is well camouflaged amongst the fallen leaves and rocks of its natural habitat.
textClean: Named for the pleated protrusions adorning its shell, this gentle turtle is well camouflaged amongst the fallen leaves and rocks of its natural habitat.

name: Uyuy Xage
textHtml: In the Hanuhanu tongue, this serpent's name translates to “large egg”─a reference to the scalekin's ever-watchful state as it protects its eggs during hatching season. The reckless few who have approached a nesting uyuy xage and survived the encounter do not recommend the experience.
textClean: In the Hanuhanu tongue, this serpent's name translates to “large egg”─a reference to the scalekin's ever-watchful state as it protects its eggs during hatching season. The reckless few who have approached a nesting uyuy xage and survived the encounter do not recommend the experience.

name: Plattershell
textHtml: This prolific crustacean is a popular food source for many living in Yok Tural, and with good reason. For a crab, it is impressively large and meaty─more than fit for a feast.
textClean: This prolific crustacean is a popular food source for many living in Yok Tural, and with good reason. For a crab, it is impressively large and meaty─more than fit for a feast.

name: Candiru
textHtml: Burrowing into flesh through open wounds and other orifices, this truly frightful wavekin consumes its prey from the inside out. To be surrounded by a shoal of these voracious predators is all but a death sentence.
textClean: Burrowing into flesh through open wounds and other orifices, this truly frightful wavekin consumes its prey from the inside out. To be surrounded by a shoal of these voracious predators is all but a death sentence.

name: Trahira
textHtml: This mottled brown wavekin effortlessly blends into its muddy habitat. When hunting, the agile fish will dart out with lethal precision, ensnaring its unlucky prey with razor-sharp fangs.
textClean: This mottled brown wavekin effortlessly blends into its muddy habitat. When hunting, the agile fish will dart out with lethal precision, ensnaring its unlucky prey with razor-sharp fangs.

name: Driftwood Catfish
textHtml: Thanks to the bark-like pattern along its sides, this fish excels at hiding among driftwood and fallen trees. The Hanuhanu in particular consider the tender, fatty flesh of this fish a delicacy.
textClean: Thanks to the bark-like pattern along its sides, this fish excels at hiding among driftwood and fallen trees. The Hanuhanu in particular consider the tender, fatty flesh of this fish a delicacy.

name: Oho Hunu
textHtml: In the Hanuhanu tongue, Oho Hunu means “windflame.” The name refers both to the wavekin's impressive speed and the burning red gradation extending to the tip of its tail fin.
textClean: In the Hanuhanu tongue, Oho Hunu means “windflame.” The name refers both to the wavekin's impressive speed and the burning red gradation extending to the tip of its tail fin.

name: Bronze Pleco
textHtml: The coloration of this bottom-feeding fish is akin to a dull metallic patina. Preferring to lurk among rocks and logs, it subsists primarily on a diet of algae.
textClean: The coloration of this bottom-feeding fish is akin to a dull metallic patina. Preferring to lurk among rocks and logs, it subsists primarily on a diet of algae.

name: Crenicichla
textHtml: This Turali cichlid's delicate fins are a sight to behold in motion─if one can find a pristine specimen. Crenicichla are possessed of a rather aggressive demeanor, and their fins often end up ragged and torn from frequent bouts of intraspecies sparring.
textClean: This Turali cichlid's delicate fins are a sight to behold in motion─if one can find a pristine specimen. Crenicichla are possessed of a rather aggressive demeanor, and their fins often end up ragged and torn from frequent bouts of intraspecies sparring.

name: Hunu Peacock Bass
textHtml: This particular species of peacock bass is distinguished by its fiery lateral markings and equally fiery temper.
textClean: This particular species of peacock bass is distinguished by its fiery lateral markings and equally fiery temper.

name: Pelubane
textHtml: The lower jaw of this voracious predator is furnished with two fearsome fangs. Capable of propelling itself out of the water, the creature is known to pounce on unsuspecting prey near the water's edge─most notably the diminutive Pelupelu.
textClean: The lower jaw of this voracious predator is furnished with two fearsome fangs. Capable of propelling itself out of the water, the creature is known to pounce on unsuspecting prey near the water's edge─most notably the diminutive Pelupelu.

name: Giant Trahira
textHtml: This devious wavekin is known to lurk on the riverbeds of Ihuykatumu, disguising itself as a rock and devouring any overly curious small fry that cross its path.
textClean: This devious wavekin is known to lurk on the riverbeds of Ihuykatumu, disguising itself as a rock and devouring any overly curious small fry that cross its path.

name: Ku'uxage Bitterling
textHtml: While bitterlings are commonly found throughout the waterways of Yok Tural, those in Ku'uxage possess a unique hunting habit. The wavekin often leap through the foamy spray of waterfalls, catching any insects in their path.
textClean: While bitterlings are commonly found throughout the waterways of Yok Tural, those in Ku'uxage possess a unique hunting habit. The wavekin often leap through the foamy spray of waterfalls, catching any insects in their path.

name: Tonguesnatcher
textHtml: According to tales from the golden age of Yok Huy society, this ancient crustacean is said to have cut out the tongues of perjurers. One look at the creature's bladelike pincers is enough to convince even the most skeptical scholars of the fables' veracity.
textClean: According to tales from the golden age of Yok Huy society, this ancient crustacean is said to have cut out the tongues of perjurers. One look at the creature's bladelike pincers is enough to convince even the most skeptical scholars of the fables' veracity.

name: Corn Dace
textHtml: This wavekin shares several similarities with the corn grown throughout Tuliyollal: a plump yellow form and prevalence on the dinner table.
textClean: This wavekin shares several similarities with the corn grown throughout Tuliyollal: a plump yellow form and prevalence on the dinner table.

name: Ka Puyhu
textHtml: The Hanuhanu word “ka” means “rainbow,” while “puhyu” describes the state of floating. A fitting name for such a graceful, iridescent wavekin. For their part, the Hanuhanu appreciate the flavor and texture of this fish as much as its beauty─dining upon it during festivals and other worthy occasions.
textClean: The Hanuhanu word “ka” means “rainbow,” while “puhyu” describes the state of floating. A fitting name for such a graceful, iridescent wavekin. For their part, the Hanuhanu appreciate the flavor and texture of this fish as much as its beauty─dining upon it during festivals and other worthy occasions.

name: Ligaka Guppy
textHtml: Lured by the promise of new discoveries, some learned Sharlayans choose to embark upon a scholarly tour of Tural in their twilight years. Clearly, creative naming was not the forte of the aging naturalist who located this species of guppy in Marsh Ligaka.
textClean: Lured by the promise of new discoveries, some learned Sharlayans choose to embark upon a scholarly tour of Tural in their twilight years. Clearly, creative naming was not the forte of the aging naturalist who located this species of guppy in Marsh Ligaka.

name: Dumplingfish
textHtml: This freshwater wavekin plies the waters of Marsh Ligaka with the aid of its large dorsal fin. The Hanuhanu, who use this fish to prepare a variety of delicious dumplings, gave it a fitting (if not slightly on the nose) name, that all who encounter it might learn of its culinary uses.
textClean: This freshwater wavekin plies the waters of Marsh Ligaka with the aid of its large dorsal fin. The Hanuhanu, who use this fish to prepare a variety of delicious dumplings, gave it a fitting (if not slightly on the nose) name, that all who encounter it might learn of its culinary uses.

name: Banded Candiru
textHtml: This variety of candiru is wreathed in scales of black and yellow─a common coloration observed in venomous wavekin. Though these hues advise predators to think twice before eating it, banded candirus are, in fact, scrumptious and completely devoid of toxins.
textClean: This variety of candiru is wreathed in scales of black and yellow─a common coloration observed in venomous wavekin. Though these hues advise predators to think twice before eating it, banded candirus are, in fact, scrumptious and completely devoid of toxins.

name: Oxydoras
textHtml: The flanks of this large wavekin are covered with a row of spines, leading some to consider its viability as a kind of scaly, living cudgel. Some ideas are best nipped in the bud before foolhardy hands are ripped to shreds by indignant catfish.
textClean: The flanks of this large wavekin are covered with a row of spines, leading some to consider its viability as a kind of scaly, living cudgel. Some ideas are best nipped in the bud before foolhardy hands are ripped to shreds by indignant catfish.

name: Spotted Stingray
textHtml: The white spots on the back of this ray are easily mistaken for eyes. Indeed, this may well be the point─to keep predators and prey alike guessing as to which way the wavekin is actually looking.
textClean: The white spots on the back of this ray are easily mistaken for eyes. Indeed, this may well be the point─to keep predators and prey alike guessing as to which way the wavekin is actually looking.

name: Yellow Peacock Bass
textHtml: When viewed on the peacock bass spectrum, this species is on the gaudier end of the scale. Despite its brazen coloring, however, this wavekin is adept at concealing itself amongst the reeds while on the hunt for prey.
textClean: When viewed on the peacock bass spectrum, this species is on the gaudier end of the scale. Despite its brazen coloring, however, this wavekin is adept at concealing itself amongst the reeds while on the hunt for prey.

name: Shovelnose Catfish
textHtml: This peculiar catfish has a slender body that tapers towards the mouth. This characteristic, along with its long barbels, helps the wavekin trawl the substrate in search for tasty insects and microbial organisms.
textClean: This peculiar catfish has a slender body that tapers towards the mouth. This characteristic, along with its long barbels, helps the wavekin trawl the substrate in search for tasty insects and microbial organisms.

name: Shimmering Shadow
textHtml: When the silver scales of this wavekin catch the light, its body appears to shimmer with a faint red glow. This enchanting effect is all the more pronounced when a shoal forms.
textClean: When the silver scales of this wavekin catch the light, its body appears to shimmer with a faint red glow. This enchanting effect is all the more pronounced when a shoal forms.

name: Ut'ohmu Dawnfish
textHtml: An undeniably beautiful wavekin that has inspired reams of sometimes questionable poetry over the years. One renowned bard had this to say of the fish: “o'er the Horizon, the first blush of dawn, drawn down to the depths by the sea's mournful call.”
textClean: An undeniably beautiful wavekin that has inspired reams of sometimes questionable poetry over the years. One renowned bard had this to say of the fish: “o'er the Horizon, the first blush of dawn, drawn down to the depths by the sea's mournful call.”

name: Belonesox
textHtml: The dark brown scales adorning this wavekin's back fade to a glistening white towards its belly. Compared to the majority of other killifish, this particular species can grow to an impressive size─as large as a Xbr'aal's hand in some cases.
textClean: The dark brown scales adorning this wavekin's back fade to a glistening white towards its belly. Compared to the majority of other killifish, this particular species can grow to an impressive size─as large as a Xbr'aal's hand in some cases.

name: Xd'aa Talat Cichlid
textHtml: According to Xbr'aal legend, this cichlid─native to Yak T'el─is favored by the spirit of the tsolys, who bestowed the wavekin with their enchanting coloration and graceful demeanor.
textClean: According to Xbr'aal legend, this cichlid─native to Yak T'el─is favored by the spirit of the tsolys, who bestowed the wavekin with their enchanting coloration and graceful demeanor.

name: Iq Br'aax Sailfin
textHtml: This elegant freshwater fish effortlessly glides through the water, using the flowing sail-like fin that runs the length of its body as a means of propulsion. It is often observed skirting the edges of the tranquil cenote it calls home.
textClean: This elegant freshwater fish effortlessly glides through the water, using the flowing sail-like fin that runs the length of its body as a means of propulsion. It is often observed skirting the edges of the tranquil cenote it calls home.

name: Hunmu Ob
textHtml: The distinctive striped pattern of this wavekin functions as camouflage when swimming through sun-dappled waters. It is little wonder, then, that the Xbr'aal name for this fish means “hidden in white.”
textClean: The distinctive striped pattern of this wavekin functions as camouflage when swimming through sun-dappled waters. It is little wonder, then, that the Xbr'aal name for this fish means “hidden in white.”

name: Apoda
textHtml: Its rather repulsive form is somewhere between a worm and a snake in appearance. When threatened, this ancient amphibian secretes a toxic slime to deter would-be predators.
textClean: Its rather repulsive form is somewhere between a worm and a snake in appearance. When threatened, this ancient amphibian secretes a toxic slime to deter would-be predators.

name: Mirror Carp
textHtml: This carp is adorned with dull, mirrorlike scales which dimly reflect driftwood and other waterborne detritus, allowing it to better conceal itself. Possessing a very mild temperament, it meanders through the waters of its habitat with an unhurried grace.
textClean: This carp is adorned with dull, mirrorlike scales which dimly reflect driftwood and other waterborne detritus, allowing it to better conceal itself. Possessing a very mild temperament, it meanders through the waters of its habitat with an unhurried grace.

name: Tsoly Mu
textHtml: In the Xbr'aal language, “mu” means “sun,” while “tsoly” refers to a cenote. A fitting name for this vibrant red wavekin, which is easily mistaken for a mysterious light source when spotted in the depths.
textClean: In the Xbr'aal language, “mu” means “sun,” while “tsoly” refers to a cenote. A fitting name for this vibrant red wavekin, which is easily mistaken for a mysterious light source when spotted in the depths.

name: Iq Rrax Leaffish
textHtml: Some say this fish struck upon its disguise when a flood of ashen leaves flowed into the waters of Iq Rrax Tsoly from the Xobr'it Cinderfield. Certainly, to the untrained eye, this wavekin is all but indistinguishable from a charred, waterborne leaf.
textClean: Some say this fish struck upon its disguise when a flood of ashen leaves flowed into the waters of Iq Rrax Tsoly from the Xobr'it Cinderfield. Certainly, to the untrained eye, this wavekin is all but indistinguishable from a charred, waterborne leaf.

name: Archmatron Angelfish
textHtml: With its majestic winglike fins and muted coloration, this wavekin has an almost ethereal presence. While similar species are found across the world, this specimen in particular has persisted unchanged for eons.
